Girls' Schooling Suffers More Than
Bo??.
"The girls' schooling begin.? to suf?
fer as soon as there Is need of any
especial assistance ?t borne. Two or
three days are dropped repeatedly.
Wage-earning sisters cannot stop at
home to nurse an invalid or care for
younger children while the mother
works. When a new baby comes, It is
the oldest school girl who carries the
extra burden of work. Evan the most
devoted mothers make these encroach
in?:.t.?, upon the time which belongs to
tho ichool. They are driven to It b>
necessity. 'What can I do? There
ain't nobody else and I've got to keep
Mamie t' help.'

pul?ory education law is an empty let- I
ter. The nine years of schooling which |

"Working in a factory is not
fun, but it brings a measure of Ir
pendence which the young persons
craves beyond all else. It Is not alw
stern need alone that sends a girl
to work at such an early age. Par?
may call upon her in times of spe
stress and insist upon her return
to school as soon as the pressure is
moved. Hut public opinion among
girls themselves .s strong and
clued upon this point.
"To continue in school after you
fret your working papers is a sign
overeducation and is not popular,
don't mind studyin', but all my frie
are goin' t' work, an' I don't wan
stay. My mother and brothers all 1
1er at me, but I'm kickin' to les
Graduate? Gee, stay two years? 1
lor me?it's too slow.'
"A girl Bees sbout her all sorts
makeshifts and haphazard expediet
One of our girls tried to avert a fi
ily disaster. Dispossession threatei
at the end of the week. Mrs. De
was in despair and helplessly she
signed the situation to Emma. W
their last $3 the girl bought a la
and some hundred printed tickets. 1
lamp was put in a saloon window. 1
tickets were to be sold in a raffle wh
was to pay the rent. They did not ?
and the rent went unpaid.

"However, rebellion and not submis?
sion is the common factor in the read?
justment which follows the girl's d?but
ss a wage earner. Along with the first
humble job and the first meagre wage,
there comes to the young girl her first
taste of power. Ht ft] I pay envelope
ia the outward and visible sign of many
changes. Her position at home is al?
tered. ?Shi has more prestige, ti.e first
beginnings of authority.
"Her family may be actually de?
pendent for comfort on what she brings
in. This gives te her desires and
?.ishes a new importance. However au
1 her parents' rule may have
been, they must now turn to her for
assistance. There must follow a cer
:atn loosening of the reins. Every now
and again there is a girl who, in these
rarly headstrong years, will press her
advantage to the full.
"Louisa used her new-found power
to add to her long day at the factory
-e-.eral nights every week at dance
I halls where she stays until 1 or
o'clock. The reproaches of her pai

like me,' she wails, T*ut you make m

Anyhow, I don't come home drunk l.k

nothing.'

that girl. I've just beat her, I have

worth o' clothes. Hut I lost my temper
She stands up and answers me back
An* she's eomin' In at 2 o'clock, me no
knowin' where she's boOO. Folks wil
I talk, you know, and it ain't right, for i
girl.'
Only An Emotional Hold Takes Effect
"The great issue between the horn?
and the girl," Miss True thinks, "is th?
question whether her affections wil
centre there. Only an emotional holt
will take effect on this girl. Her mine
is underdeveloped. She is not goln?
to reason far. Habit has not yet fast?
ened her into a nit of eternal work anc
decency. If she has become estrange?:
from those who are naturally near U
! her, she is set adrift. She is bound tr
1 express in some way the chaotic emo
! tional forces within her.
"The will to play is strong in th<
' fourteen to eighteen-year-old girl
[ Lack-lustre resignation and pessimism
? are rare among the young, even where
' poverty weighs most heavily. Thl
girl's buoyant spirit breaks loose at
! the instant of release from factory
walls or from the momentary -
sion o{ family want.

Some of them succumb and get

Many of them have never lived on a
itly high moral level to 'fall.'

re .red A smattering of cotventlonal

school is of little practi.-al f.irce
